reviewText: The short version: this is an insane game for insane people, and I loved nearly every moment of it.\n\nThe long version: this starts as, basically, Sokoban, but quickly reveals itself as much more than that: the spheres (or larvae") you push "simulate gravity as camouflage" i.e. fall in the direction dependant on how they wre pushed. The difficulty past the first five or six levels skyrockets
date: and the game keeps piling up new mechanics on you until almost the very end. It requires excellent spatial awareness
recommended: but the feeling of satisfaction after cracking a particularly fiendish puzzle is unparalleled. The levels are ordered in semi-nonlinear fashion
hoursPlayed: but there are several "chokepoints" that may block you from further progress for hours as you despair for a solution.\n\nThe presentation is very simplistic (as you van see from the screenshots)
voteText: but clear and legible. The sound and music are
votesTotal: with ambient humming and chanting.\n\nYou will get stuck. More than once. And you'll love it."

reviewText: I am recommending this game, but it is important to note that this is not a universal recommendation.\n\nThis is a puzzle collection, and honestly a pretty good one - there's a wide variety of puzzle types
date: but some of them are VERY difficult. Expect to be challenged, and do NOT expect to sit down and crank through a bunch of these in a single sitting. For folks who are not looking for difficult, abstract, mind-bendy 3D puzzles? Definitely not the place to look.\n\nThat being said, I had a good time with it for the most part. Some of them were just plain old DAMN hard, but when I felt like I had some degree of comprehension of what was needed, it was a good type of challenging.

reviewText: In all honsety, I'm putting this game up there with the expert mode of super monkey ball. It's just insanse. It does share the tools that made smb great though, you can instantly restart a level with the press of the button, when you fail, and failing will come often here, you also get the turn back by one move feature, which is great for experimenting when your not sure , powering through with trial and error, or salvaging a run on one of the later puzzles. Together these make the game bearable.\n\nYou play as a square which flips from space to space, but it throws new things at you constantly. One of the most notable, is that gravity is determined in the direction that you move, and only for things you come into contact with, which is one of the hardest conceptual challenges I've faced in a long time. You'll have to deal with the cube based nature of the game on another level when you are asked to cut' specific shapes into your square

reviewText:
English Country Tune, an inexplicably-named geometrical, abstract puzzle game. First of all, the soundtrack isn't English or Country... though it is a tune (albeit not an amazing one). And while this review may have started negatively, my opinion of English Country Tune is anything but. Simply because it is a very good puzzle game and that it's everything it's aspiring to be. The puzzles are based on those movement or arranging puzzles where you have to move certain objects to certain locations (some further research lead me to a style of puzzle called Sokoban).

Overall, the game has the feel of an end of degree, final project except for one difference. The gameplay and level design is actually well-refined with a lot of thought and time going into each level. The harder puzzles have only one solution with only an undo button and reset button to help you through (or help you backtrack). The graphics are rudimentary and there is no initial instruction in the menu screen. It took me a while to work out how to access the puzzles. And while the graphics are basic, they are perfect for this game.

For full review, visit:
http://icarusreviews.net/2014/10/15/brief-write-of-a-brief-flight-english-country-tune/

reviewText: This is a good puzzle game. But my biggest gripes are the frustrating camera angles, and the unintuitive level select menu. Better complete each world in one go, because if you skip some puzzles you're gonna have a frustrating time finding them later on with this awful menu.\nSome of the hardest puzzles of the game also happen to be in some of the earliest worlds in the game, while a lot of the later worlds are a breeze. I also don't like the levels that make you build the puzzle yourself. Overall though, this is a good game and I enjoyed it. Give it a go if you like these sorts of games.

reviewText: This is a very hard 3D puzzle game with wildly varying mechanics built in the unity engine. There are balls that fall differently depending on where you hit them (their gravity changes), boxes that only move when you push the light that beams from all sides, and those step on all the blocks puzzles. One world consists of levels that require you to actually build the level until it is covered in immobile, impassible cubes that result from your every other step, and that's where I gave up. There is no story; it is just a bunch of gated puzzles. Also, don't expect any great soundtrack, despite the name, because it's all ambient music. That being said, if you want a ton of challenging logic puzzles, this is the game for you.

reviewText: Well this is an interesting take on the puzzle genre. Rather than sticking with a single set of mechanics and making loads of puzzles off of them, this one goes the opposite route of having lots of related mechanics and making a small number of puzzles off of each one. It doesn't work quite as well as the first approach - for example, I'd put Puzzle Dimension over this one - an it does have that odd moment of not being sure what to do next because you don't fully understand a mechanic, but it's still quite a fun game nonetheless. I'd certainly recommend it!

reviewText:
English Country Tune has some similarities to sokoban, and yet it has a very different gameplay.

The game looks simple, but don't underestimate the puzzles and the rising difficulty to the puzzles. You will need time and a good tactic to solve some of the riddles included. You can take the riddles step by step or try to solve them as fast as you like. The game is quite good, but I think it might not be a game for everybody. Mostly because it looks like an underdog. Don't get fooled by the looks - it has it's stings and you might not see the solution of some riddles on the first few tries.

reviewText: The game is fun and pushes you to think over and over again till you find a way. {Assuming you don't watch walkthroughs which I don't recommend.} Get it! It's wonderful.

Extremely simplistic and minimalistic looking game, English Country Tune is a very slick puzzle game that starts out gentle but quickly ramps the difficulty up to brain buster.  The game play consists of moving a blue tile around a 3D map, flipping it over as you go, and using it to solve a multitude of puzzle worlds, which there are over a dozen of.  Puzzles can consist of simply moving a cube to the end of a level, to having to cover a level with impassable blocks which are planted by one side of your tile, to punching holes in your tile so it becomes a key for a lock.  Fun to look at, easy to learn, hard to master.  The dozens of puzzle worlds will keep you busy for hours.
Masterpiece of level design and clever puzzles.\nEveryone who loves puzzle games should buy this instantly!

Designing a good puzzle game is difficult. In too many entries in this genre, you will get either a very limited set of rule that does not allow for creative puzzles or so many new rules along the way that none feel properly explored in their puzzle design potential. You will often get totally trivial levels at first that rapidly evolve into extraordinarily difficult puzzles or extraordinarily tedious ones. The brilliance of Increpare's English Country Tune is that it finds almost the perfect balance and avoid all of these pitfalls to offer constant challenge and clever use of its mechanisms.\n\nThis is not the most welcoming game and some of the fundamental rules are a tad tricky to assimilate, but it is an extremely rewarding game packed full with superb level design.

Awesome logic game.\nThe difficulty is quite high, as one has to complete every level in an area to progress further and the puzzles can be really challenging... But after all this is what matters and the reason why this game so good ;)

3D Sokoban with complex rules. There aren't very many types of blocks to get used to, but the rules governing each of them are surprisingly deep, and even at the beginning of the game, you really have to understand all of the subtle rules thoroughly in order to plan ahead and complete each level. For example, the larva" blocks are pushed around when you run into them. But gravity applies to them selectively
date: and you absolutely must understand how gravity works in order to get them to fall into the right positions.\n\nBecause of the complex rules
recommended: you need to plan ahead - guessing rarely gets you to the correct solution. And as a result
helpfulPercent: gives a Dark Souls-like satisfaction. You *earn* your victories!\n\nSome of the other reviewers don't like the minimalist
votesTotal: but I think they're beautiful. You can see for yourself what it looks like form the screenshots and videos and decide if the art is up your alley or not."

reviewText:
Ignore the name. The name has nothing to do with anything about the game.

This is a pure puzzle game. One part 3D sokoban, one part Koenigsburg bridges, and about fifteen parts of evil genius. It's a game of discovery, where you may not know exactly what you need to do.

Either you're looking at this description and wondering why anyone would want this, or you're salivating at the prospect. If you're in the first group, go buy a different game. Life is too short to play games that aren't up your alley. I won't judge. There's a lot of popular games out there that aren't my speed.

If you're in the second group, you should have already played this game. But if you haven't, buy it now.

If you like puzzles, this game can give you a challenge, and the diversity of puzzles will act as another challege unto itself. However, this is strictly a puzzle game. There is absolutely no motive. No point system. No time limit. Nothing.\n\nThere's better puzzles games out there, but this one does nicely for your money.

reviewText: English Country Tune is a bit of a nightmarish cross between a rubix cube and one of those block pusher puzzle games. The first few levels are straightforward enough, but the complexity and introduction of mechanics and conditions escalates at an overwhelming rate. The idea is fairly novel, but before I was able to feel any reward for overcoming that first spike in difficulty, the game had already overstayed its welcome and I was ready to move on to greener pastures.

reviewText:
First off, the positive stuff: It's a great collection of puzzles. If you can enjoy playing a modest variety of Sokoban remakes for any prolonged period of time, then you certainly should buy this.

The negative stuff: What I wrote above is exactly what the game is - a collection of interesting Sokoban variants. Every level set has slightly different rules, but it's still just a bunch of increasingly difficult puzzles, with no extra value. Even the graphical impression is quite plain and uninteresting.

Not a worst buy I ever made, but there are tons of better puzzle games to spend those few bucks on, hence 'nay' from me.

reviewText: The game lacks charm, going for an almost minimalist esoteric aesthetic but ending up just looking bland. The mechanics are confusing, but I've had no need to understand them, since I was able to get through a fair chunk of the game just going along the one route the puzzle lets me take and making minor adjustments when I fail. No thought required. It's not a bad game per se, but there are much better puzzle games out there. If the aesthetic interests you, I'd recommend checking out TRI: Of Friendship and Madness instead. That game has both better puzzles and a much more satisfying atmosphere, in the same minimalist aesthetic.

reviewText:
Some obscure pretentious puzzling anyone? We play as a polyurethane mat flapping across chequered 3d structures and score balls into holes. It demands some getting used to the pequliar Unity engine physics and the restrictions of game rules you mostly figure out for yourself. Based on artificial logic it's levels provide some challenge to the mind (checkers math). Didn't notice anything english, rural or melodic about it.
5 O'clock out of half past ten

Немного претенциозного головоломства кому-нибудь? Играем за полиуретановый мат, шлепающий по клетчатым трехмерным объектам, заталкивая шарики в дырки. Это требует привыкания и к особенной физике движка Единство, и к ограничениям правил игры, которые придется в основном выяснять самому. Уровни, основанные на искусственной логике, бросают определенный вызов уму (математика шашек). Ничего особо английского, деревенского или мелодичного не замечено.

reviewText: I've had my eye on this game for more than a year and I'm so glad I didn't miss it this sale around!  If you like puzzles and challenging your brain, I definitely recommend it.  The soundtrack is quiet and soothing, and it's a nice game if you want to wind down for an hour or so at a time...or if you just want to switch it up from shooting, running, jumping, hacking and slashing.  As far as the length of the game, I'm not even halfway through it, but I am a slow puzzler.  That said, I think it's definitely worth the 4.99$ purchase price and, if you get it at 90% off during a sale like I did, you will have no complaints!  I mean, ok... you might, but that's probably just because you're prone to complaining in general.

reviewText: Very little English, Rural or Melodious. I picked this up as part of a Humble Bundle and decided to give it a go. A serious mind bending puzzle game. It gently reveals the mechanics and goals, and leaves it to you. Great for exercising the grey cells and not the adrenal gland. Expect to be frustrated if 3-dimensional puzzle solving isn't your thing, but one certainly feels a sense of accomplishment when one discovers the elegant solutions to a the geometric puzzles. Personally I found the colour scheme rather jarring after a while, which was on the whole good since I was able to stop playing to rest my eyes. Otherwise I'd have been solving puzzles all night.
A true puzzle game, and if it seems simple as you start it, don't worry. It will keep throwing stuff at you until you get to levels that keep you scratching your head for days. Get it!
Great game. I was stuck many times, but never frustrated.

I bought this game on a whim, I often enjoy the odd puzzle game and thought I'd give it a try.\nThe first thing I noticed about this game were the rather quaint aesthetics and atmosphere. The game has a somewhat lax feel almost begging the player to continue. The varied puzzle types keep the game interesting and at times unforgiving. I'll be stuck on a level for a while, then out of nowhere an answer will appear making me feel like I've learnt, adapted and achieved something I had previously not been able to do or figure out.\nI got this on sale, for 39p, but this game is definitely worth the full price and is a must-have for puzzle fanatics or just the casual gamer... or everyone basically.
Truly a 3D puzzle game.\nDifficulty ramps up and you WILL need to use your brain. If you like challenges, this one is for you.
Excellent puzzle game, very calming. There are flickery smudges that really add to the atmosphere, but might not be great if you are really phobic of bugs, due to the way they move.
If you want something logic, then English country tune is the right choice !!\nBeggining isnt very hard but advanced parts of the games are.... something like hell :)

English Country tune is a beautiful, mysterious, frustrating game. It's hard. Every level's a brain teaser. It might make you feel stupid. It's full of gorgeous puzzles that are both unlike anything you've seen befor and utterly unique amongst each other. I'm not one for puzzle games, but the atmosphere and ambience of this game create a truely singular experience. Even if you don't think you like puzzle games, you should play this if only to say that you have.
WHISTLE THIS.
A really interesting abstract puzzle game that has nothing to do with the English, the country or tunes, however it's very difficult and fun to play, and there are many different types of levels.

I just discovered this game. But I'm familiar with the creator, Increpare, who is known for making awfuly complex and mindbending web games at increpare.com. His games tend to lack guidance or anything that would tell you how to play them or what the objective is at all. But don't be fooled, these are bonafide games with well defined mechanics and objectives, as obtuse as they might appear to be.\n\nThis game is both more ambitious and somewhat kind of a let down in the sense that I was dissapointed when I saw the first tutorial" question mark in the game. I really hoped to see zero instructions and be completelly baffled not knowing what to do for the first 15 minutes. In addition to this
date: compared to most of his other games
recommended: ECT is actually more simple. I would have probaby figured out the mechanics rather quickly without any kind of help anyway. But I'm not being kind by comparing this game to his more experimental and way less accessible creations.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: this is still a very good puzzle game. One of the best around.\n\nI'll probably ammend this review once I have played it for a few more hours."

reviewText: The five hours I've spent with this game have been exotic, varied and challenging. If you think 'puzzle game' is a genre, this game is out to show you that there are so many ways to present you problems to solve. To have this game is like owning dozens of those mind game" tree toys. Except this is more psychedelic and advanced."
basic but fun and challenging
Nice game that will give you a lot of WTF?!?" moments"
One of the best puzzle games I've played. Original, well crafted and with a classy design. Difficult but so satisfying.
The puzzles are complex and innovative without seeming unfair. It offers plenty of fun logical insights. Overall, it's a fantastic puzzle game at a bargain price.
it's a really creative puzzle game and it's not expensive, plus there's plenty to do it's a great game
Truly a 3D puzzle game.\nDifficulty ramps up and you WILL need to use your brain. If you like challenges, this one is for you.

TL;DR: This game is incredible!

These are different types of geometrical riddles. They're a challenge at times (which is what you want from a game like this) and change style A LOT! It also fully runs on Linux without any problems whatsoever. A small perk: the menu is very interestingly styled. For a cheap price highly recommended!

This is perhaps the single most brilliantly designed puzzle game I have ever encountered.

This is some pure, raw, intense puzzling. Just balls and squares and lines and your brain. And it can get brutal. One particularly merciless puzzle (very mild spoiler) requires you to build your OWN puzzle and solve it. You'll spend 30 minutes just figuring out how to design a puzzle that is solvable in the first place. Most puzzles will take you a few minutes, but you'll eventually be stumped, and you'll fiddle around with one for an hour. This game is perfect for masochists.

This game came with a humble bundle, so I didn't really feel entitled to anything, and basically just launched the game because why not.\n\nEither way... it's turned out to be a rather pleasant experience. The gameplay - which incidentally has nothing to do with the English, or country tunes - consists mostly of various more-or-less creative block pushing puzzles. The first - Larva" - has blocks that fall in different directions depending on which direction they are pushed in
date: which is a pretty neat idea. The quality of the puzzles varies (never truly reaching very high or very low quality)
recommended: and I never really got stuck. There are several variations on the basic principle
hoursPlayed: which I guess is neat.\n\nIn general

reviewText: One of the best puzzle games I've played in a long time. It seems very difficult at first, until you learn its own abstract physics laws quirks, then it becomes... between relaxing and difficult.

For puzzle fans, yes, this is absolutely a wonderful collections of puzzles. As mentioned in other reviews, the difficulty curve is fairly steep. They didn't toss in any filler stages that let you coast along for a false sense of accomplishment. Each stage asks you to think about it in a slightly different way from the last. Very well thought out and implemented game.

First off, The title of the game makes no sense at all.
Also this is a puzzle game, and I hate puzzles.
This game doesn't have a story or charcters.

But

Its probably one of the best puzzle games I've played, The details and music are just insane, The way the the menu is layed out it feels like your already playing the game.

Highly recommned this if you like puzzles or even if your just stressed out and just play this for a while. Its not the best game but one of the best puzzle games I've seen.
this is without a doubt one of the best puzzle games ive ever played. i srsly recommend it. bigtime

Stunning puzzle game, best I've played by far - 10/10. Copied below is my review on metacritic:

Superb game, and near-perfect in it's execution and atmosphere, English Country Tune is a deep meditation on 3-dimensional space.

The game presents a series of puzzles in a rich and mysterious world that even in the beginning can be quite challenging. Through the rapid introduction of interacting variables in the puzzle space, the challenge reaches such a degree of difficulty that only sustained meditation and visualisation of possibilities will generate a solution.

This could have been a lot of un-fun work, but somehow the combination of atmospheric and uninterrupted music, colours and a space that is utterly joyous to navigate make this game one of the most incredible experiences of any I've played. I distinctly remember feeling moments where my neurons connected in ways I did not think possible, and the satisfaction of finding a solution was often overwhelmingly pleasurable.

Highly recommended, very original, and best played without a walkthough, and resetting puzzles instead of using the undo function.

I'll be honest, I'd never heard of this before it showed up in the Humble Bundle. But it's a wonderfully clever little puzzle game that's not like anything else out there, and I've enjoyed it more than some of the games I actually intended to buy.
Absolutely brilliant puzzle game, adds a great twist to a classic formula, and plenty of levels of play. Not for the geometrically-challenged though.
Simple, and quick!  The puzzles are not mind-melting insane, but they leave a satisfying, clean taste in your brain after solving them.

Not my kind of game but if you like puzzles I suppose this would be pretty fun! It has a lot of variety from what I've seen in others playing and in my short experience with it. the mechanics took a bit of getting used to and the camera angles could be kinda wonky sometimes.
hard but very rewarding and beautiful
amazing game not gay like it looks fun game for the price
i got stuck in this but the puzzles i could solve were really fun. but the metagame is bad, you are likely to get stuck and give up.

It will eventually fill your tiny brain with puzzles so complex you will do only a couple each day, since you are thinking and scared of the puzzles at night. And when you get stuck, you will spend hours on your computer just thinking, not move, just thinking. It will ruin you day. On the bright side, it will bring your IQ to 150.
If Sokoban and Satan had a child together, this would be the result. Fiendishly difficult once you get past the opening parts.

Maddenly complex and put-your-foot-through-the-monitor hard, the solutions to ETC's puzzles will elude you for hours, maybe even days or weeks, as you fight through endless mazes of reletivistic gravity and general mind-♥♥♥♥ery. You will feel very stupid and then suddenly very intelligent, then very stupid as you solve each relentlessly genious puzzle.\n\nIt's only 499 pennies. What are you waiting for?
My favorite puzzle game of all time

This is an abstract puzzle game that teaches you how to play as you go along. It feels a bit like 3D Sokoban, but with additional mechanics that keep ramping up and combining in interesting ways. A couple good hours have beaten about six worlds (levels grouped by mechanic, maybe around two dozen levels in all) and unlocked several more for me, which is just a good start in this complex game.

Just like I read in Rock Paper Shotgun, when you think ahead and solve a hard problem, this game makes you feel like a total genius. Just like solving a particularly hard Portal level.

If I had one complaint, it's that you can solve a fair number of early puzzles by dinking around randomly until you arrive at the solution. Seconds later, you may have forgotten what you did. Ideally, you should be forced to figure it out before you solve it.
OOOOOO. Puzzles.

TL;DR: This game is incredible!

These are different types of geometrical riddles. They're a challenge at times (which is what you want from a game like this) and change style A LOT! It also fully runs on Linux without any problems whatsoever. A small perk: the menu is very interestingly styled. For a cheap price highly recommended!

Subjective final score:
8/10

I shaved off points for in-game textures of the world and music, plus missing labels in the menu. They're all minor complaints in comparison to gameplay and such, but you don't want to give a game 10/10 when it's not absolutely perfect ;) ... I tend to be rather strict.

Big thumbs up.
ECT is a difficult puzzle game that operates in three planes. The graphics are spartan and well-done, and the ruleset remains simple throughout the game.
If you enjoy puzzle games, try this one out! Usually I feel kind of cheated in puzzle games but this one is good
asd

I am still not done with this game but I think I can safely say that this is one of the best collections of puzzles you can experience in a game, probably period.

Unconcerned with trivial concepts like conventional gravity and the laws of physics, this game, even in its crazier moments, never ends up feeling obtuse or alienating, but rather challenging and enticing. If one feels completely overwhelmed by a particular puzzle, oftentimes the best way to go is to leave the game, get some rest, let your brain do the work, and come back to it fresh the next morning, and more often than not it will solve itself.

Fortunately, thanks to its very well made undo feature (that also works to undo a restart by the way !), it encourages experimentation and as a result never feels frustrating. Even better, the beautiful ambient score (on more than one occasion reminiscent of artists like Steve Roach, for example) ensures that the experience is often more soothing than stressful : unlike a lot of puzzle games, there is no stress element in English Country Tune, no timer, no lives, no limited continues. It's just you and a bunch of extremely well-designed, unique puzzles.

Highly recommended for anyone who enjoys a good brain teaser.
simple, brilliant, elegant and classy. I love it. And for the price is a really good buy.\nrecommend it.
Cute game. Not enough tutoral.
Made my Parkinson's go away.\n\n10/5 Would let Obama make into a sequel

Really hard. And if you get stuck and can't figure out the solution, guides are the only help. But that removes the fun from the game. And you can't skip a level and move on.

Do not let the name of the game fool you. This is actually a pretty interesting puzzler. They graphics are minamalistic, the music is soothing, and the mechanincs are intriguing. If you worry about playing puzzlers and messing up, then having to go back to the beginning of the puzzle, fret not! This game give you the ability to undo moves as well are restart the puzzle. I got two worlds in, and given the curve I think that the rest of the game will be as good as the beginning.
This was quite a tough puzzle game. I only needed help with one level.

A block-based puzzle where you push things to their designated place. I have completed two worlds (different worlds seem to have different variations on the same principle) and it's already pretty difficult. I didn't find it very enjoyable though. Maybe it's the ugly graphics or the lack of music (there is only ambient noise).

English Country Tune uses 3D very well in its challenging, logical puzzles. The gameplay constantly surprises me with new ideas and goes against my expectations, against my intuition and everything I know about our universe. It does that in a very beautiful, mind expanding way. But you really need to be ready to put in the mental effort in order to reap the rewards.
best game eeevveeeerrrrrr

My Life As A Teenage Rectangle has provided a thorough and groundbreaking escape from the tried and true tropes commonly found in the video game industry. In this game you play as the aptly named polygon, Wrecky the Rectangle, and experience the life of a rectangle in glorious high definition. A profound narrative combined with pulse pounding music and beautiful graphics make this a staple in any true gamer’s library.

8/10

I especially liked the tricky ones where you have to build the level yourself! Seriously brain-bending. I couldn't figure out Lesson" while looking at it but I sat up in the middle of the night and shouted "AHA!" much to my wife's chagrin.

Looking forward to the next one from this developer."

One of the true puzzle greats that really deserves more love.

Where English Country Tune really shines is in its impeccable design; even Braid wasn't this crisp.
- Unbelievably innovative puzzle mechanics (Portrait was my personal favorite)
- Terrific learning curve, with plenty of easier puzzles to teach you about the hard ones
- Fiendishly difficult puzzles (I'm looking at you, Half-Sided)
- Somehow, every single puzzle feels deliberate and well-designed. You absolutely have to know what you're doing to beat any level.

I got it through a Humble Bundle, but I would easily pay much more than five dollars for this experience again. Eagerly awaiting Increpare's future projects!
